UML:TaggedValue.value:
The package instances describes an extension to the MOF (M3) model. It is used to create instances of M2 concepts on M2 level. Although instantiation is a part of the UML Infrastructure library (core.abstraction.instances) it is nessary for two reasons.
First, instance is not a first class M3-level concept. Instances can be modeled as MOF classes, but this does not include a special semantics. A instance models using the class concept, will behave like any other class instance. But what is the additional semantic needed? A instance distinguishes itself from a class, becaus an instance references a classifier (e.g. the defining class). This is confusing, because a class, as any other model element, has a classifier too. But those meta-classifiers reside on a different meta-level and serve a completly different purpose.
To understand instances loose yourself a second from different meta-levels and take the concepts classifier and instance as something god given. Both an instance and its classifier reside on the same level (e.g. Class and Object, BlockType and TypeBasedBlockInstance). The classifier describes a type and a set of instances; the instance describes a realisation of the classifier. Back to the meta-levels, both are concepts, and thus they are both classified by a class on the meta-level above.
And here lays the problem: A class simply describes a M3 concepts that allows it instances on M2 to be instanciated on M1. But what we need is an instance M3 concept. That would be a M3 concept that allows it instances on M2 to be instanciated on M1 as instances of an M1 classifier. Of course this could also be done by modelling the instanceof relationship on M2 level (this is actually done in the core.abstractions.instances package). But this has to be done for each instance kind (M2 instance concept) that one would like to define. And worse, when moving to M1, where the actual instance instances are created, they always have to be related to they corresponding classifiers manually, because there is no such semantics defined on M3-level.
The second problem are single (implicit) instances and instance sets. Many languages, including SDL, allow implicit instances (or implicit types). In SDL for example you can define a Process. If you see the Process definition as a classifier it is implicitly instanciated; or if you see the Process definition as an instance definition, an implicit type is created. Eitherway using a single definition to different instances of the different concepts are created: a classifier (the Processtype) and an instance (the Process itself). The package instances models this kind of implicit instanciation (or implicit classification) as special classifier concept.

To model a language completly, three models are needed: a syntax model, a semantics model, and an output (or behaviour) model. The syntax model describes the language structure, its concepts, it can be compared to the definition of an abstract syntax in compiler design. For this model normal metamodelling techniques are used; it is usally a MOF model. The semantics model, describes the semantics of the language, it defines instances for the concepts introduced in the syntax model and defines operational semantics for those instances. The idea is that the instance for each concepts defines operations that can execute all semantics attached to the language concept. The Instances package, and its M3-model enhancements should be used for this kind of modelling. The third model, the output model, is used to define the syntax for a behaviour. Whereby behaviour means a sequential representation of the states and actions of a possible system run. Such behaviours can be used to verify, execute, test, and display the working semantics of a language.
